00002 #
00003 # Fraction object
00004 # Keeps track of two variables- numerator and denominator.
00005 # Has subroutines for basic arithmatic functions, for anything 
00006 # more complicated, it can return a scalar value of 
00007 # numerator/denominator.
00008 # VS 7/20/2000
00009 
00010 
00011 =head3 Fraction
00012 
00013   This object is designed to ease the use of fractions
00014 
00015 =head4 Variables and Methods
00016 
00017     Variables
00018 
00019         numerator   #numerator of fraction
00020         denominator #denominator of fraction
00021 
00022     Arithmetic Methods  #these will all accept a scalar value or 
00023                 #another fraction as an argument
00024 
00025         plus        #returns the sum of the fraction and argument
00026         minus       #returns fraction minus argument
00027         subtractFrom    #returns argument minus fraction
00028         divBy       #returns fraction divided by argument
00029         divInto     #returns argument divided by fraction
00030         times       #returns fraction times argument
00031         compare     #returns <, =, or > for the relation of fraction to argument
00032 
00033             pow     #returns fraction raised to argument, a given integer power
00034 
00035 
00036     Other methods
00037         
00038         reduce      #reduces to lowest terms, and makes sure denominator is positive
00039         scalar      #returns the scalar value numerator/denominator
00040         print       #prints the fraction
00041         print_mixed #prints the fractionas a mixed number
00042         print_inline    #prints the fraction like this 2/3
00043 
00044 
00045 =head4 Synopsis
00046 
00047     The fraction object stores two variables, numerator and denominator.  The basic
00048 arithmatic methods listed above can be performed on a fraction, and it can return its own
00049 scalar value for use with functions expecting a scalar (ie, sqrt($frac->scalar) ).  
00050 
00051 
00052 =cut

00055 BEGIN {
00056     be_strict();
00057 }

00059 package Fraction;

00061 
00062 my %fields = (
00063     numerator   =>  undef,
00064     denominator =>  undef,
00065 );
00066 
00067 
00068 sub new {
00069 
00070     my $class = shift;
00071     my @input = @_;
00072     my $num; 
00073     my $denom;
00074 
00075     unless (@_ == 1 or @_ == 2) {
00076         warn "Invalid number of arguments to create new Fraction.  Use the form new Fraction(numerator,
00077         denominator) or new Fraction(value) to send a single scalar.";
00078         }
00079 
00080     # if we've been given a scalar as input:
00081     # this will ensure that the numerator is a whole number.  If it is not, this will
00082     # multiply by 10 until it is a whole number, keeping track of the appropriate denominator.
00083     # The loop conditional checks that the difference between the number and its int value 
00084     # is less than .000000001, NOT that they are equal.  Because of imprecisions with floating
00085     # point numbers, checking for equality will NOT work in many cases.
00086 
00087     if (@_ == 1) {
00088         my $tempDenom = 1;
00089         while ($input[0] - int($input[0]) > .000000001) {$input[0] *= 10; $tempDenom *= 10;}
00090         $num = $input[0];
00091         $denom = $tempDenom;
00092     }
00093  
00094     else { $num = $input[0]; $denom = $input[1]; }
00095     
00096 
00097     my $self = {
00098         _permitted  =>  \%fields,
00099         numerator   =>  $num,
00100         denominator =>  $denom,
00101     };
00102     
00103     bless $self, $class;
00104     
00105     return $self;
00106 }

00111 sub numerator {
00112     my $self = shift;
00113     my $type = ref($self) || die "$self is not an object";
00114     unless (exists $self->{numerator} ) {
00115         die "Can't find numerator field in object of class $type";
00116     }
00117     
00118     if (@_) {
00119         return $self->{numerator} = shift;
00120     } else {
00121         return $self->{numerator}
00122     }
00123 }
00124 
00125 sub denominator {
00126     my $self = shift;
00127     my $type = ref($self) || die "$self is not an object";
00128     unless (exists $self->{denominator} ) {
00129         die "Can't find denominator field in object of class $type";
00130     }
00131     
00132     if (@_) {
00133         return $self->{denominator} = shift;
00134     } else {
00135         return $self->{denominator}
00136     }
00137 }

00144 ###################################################################################
00145 # Basic Arithmetic Methods
00146 # Each returns a new Fraction appropriate to the operation
00147 
00148 sub plus {
00149     my $self = shift;
00150     my $input = shift;
00151     
00152     $input = new Fraction($input*100, 100) unless (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00153 
00154     my $lcm = $self->lcm($self->{denominator}, $input->{denominator});
00155     my $scaleA = $lcm/$self->{denominator};
00156     my $scaleB = $lcm/$input->{denominator};
00157 
00158     my $num = $self->{numerator}*$scaleA + $input->{numerator}*$scaleB;
00159 
00160     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $lcm);
00161     $frac->reduce;
00162     $frac;
00163 }
00164 
00165 sub minus {
00166     my $self = shift;
00167     my $input = shift;
00168 
00169     $input = new Fraction($input*100, 100) unless (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00170 
00171     my $lcm = $self->lcm($self->{denominator}, $input->{denominator});
00172     my $scaleA = $lcm/$self->{denominator};
00173     my $scaleB = $lcm/$input->{denominator};
00174 
00175     my $num = $self->{numerator}*$scaleA - $input->{numerator}*$scaleB;
00176         
00177     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $lcm);
00178     $frac->reduce;
00179     $frac;
00180 }
00181 
00182 sub subtractFrom {
00183     my $self = shift;
00184     my $input = shift;  
00185 
00186     $input = new Fraction($input*100, 100) unless (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00187          
00188     my $lcm = $self->lcm($self->{denominator}, $input->{denominator});
00189     my $scaleA = $lcm/$self->{denominator};
00190     my $scaleB = $lcm/$input->{denominator};
00191 
00192     my $num = $input->{numerator}*$scaleB - $self->{numerator}*$scaleA;
00193 
00194     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $lcm);
00195     $frac->reduce;
00196     $frac;
00197 }
00198 
00199 sub divInto {
00200     my $self = shift;
00201     my $input = shift;  
00202 
00203     $input = new Fraction($input*100, 100) unless (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00204          
00205     my $num = $input->{numerator}*$self->{denominator};
00206     my $denom = $input->{denominator}*$self->{numerator};
00207 
00208     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $denom);
00209     $frac->reduce;
00210     $frac;
00211 }

00218         
00219     my $num = $self->{numerator}*$input->{denominator};
00220     my $denom = $input->{numerator}*$self->{denominator};
00221                             
00222     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $denom);
00223     $frac->reduce;
00224     $frac;
00225 }       
00226 
00227 sub times {
00228     my $self = shift;
00229     my $input = shift;
00230 
00231     $input = new Fraction($input*100, 100) unless (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00232         
00233     my $num = $self->{numerator}*$input->{numerator};
00234     my $denom = $self->{denominator}*$input->{denominator};
00235 
00236     my $frac = new Fraction($num, $denom);
00237     $frac->reduce;
00238     $frac;
00239 }
00240 
00241 sub pow {
00242     
00243     my $self = shift;
00244     my $input = shift;
00245 
00246     if($input == 0) { # 0 power, always return 1
00247         if($self->{numerator} == 0) {
00248             warn "Indeterminant form, 0^0, in Fraction power";
00249         }
00250         return new Fraction(1,0);
00251     }
00252 
00253     my ($n, $d);
00254     
00255     if($input<0) {
00256         $d = $self->{numerator};
00257         $n = $self->{denominator};
00258         if($d==0) {
00259             warn "Computing 1/0 in Fraction";
00260         }
00261         $input = -$input;
00262     } else {
00263         $n = $self->{numerator};
00264         $d = $self->{denominator};
00265     }
00266     my $g = $self->gcd($n, $d);
00267     if($d<0) {$g = -$g;}
00268     $n /= $g;
00269     $d /= $g;
00270 
00271     return new Fraction($n**$input, $d**$input);
00272 
00273 }

00275 #########################################################################

00279 # returns a string denoting relation-- < = or >
00280 # a string is returned for ease of use in writing problems
00281 sub compare {
00282     my $self = shift;
00283     my $input = shift;
00284 
00285     $input = $input->scalar if (ref($input) eq "Fraction");
00286 
00287     my $relation = undef;
00288     $relation = "<" if ($self->scalar < $input);
00289     $relation = "=" if ($self->scalar == $input);
00290     $relation = ">" if ($self->scalar > $input);
00291 
00292     $relation;
00293 }

00296 # returns the scalar value of numerator/denominator
00297 sub scalar {
00298     my $self = shift;
00299     my $scalar = $self->{numerator}/$self->{denominator};
00300     
00301     $scalar;
00302 }
00303 
00304 
00305 # reduces a fraction to lowest terms, and makes denominator positive
00306 sub reduce {
00307     
00308     my $self = shift;   
00309     my $gcd = $self->gcd($self->{numerator}, $self->{denominator});
00310     if($self->{denominator}<0) {$gcd = -$gcd;}
00311     
00312     $self->{numerator} = $self->{numerator}/$gcd;
00313     $self->{denominator} = $self->{denominator}/$gcd;
00314 }
00315 
00316 
00317 # standard print method.  Outputs string containing fraction displayed (in math mode
00318 # if needed).
00319 sub print {
00320     my $self = shift;
00321     my $out;
00322 
00323     # if it's a whole number, just print the number
00324     if ($self->{denominator} == 1) {
00325         $out = $self->{numerator};
00326     }
00327     # positive fraction: print out in plain math mode
00328     elsif ($self->scalar > 0) {
00329         $out = " \\frac{$self->{numerator}}{$self->{denominator}} ";
00330     }
00331     # negative fraction: print out negative sign and then absolute value in 
00332     # fraction form, avoiding parenthesis around the negative portion.
00333     else {
00334         my $foo = -$self->{numerator}; 
00335         $out = "  -\\frac{$foo}{$self->{denominator}} ";
00336     }
00337     
00338     $out;
00339 }
00340 
00341 # forces printing of a mixed number, if applicable.
00342 sub print_mixed {
00343     my $self = shift;
00344     my $out;
00345     
00346     # if it's not an improper, just pass on to the regular print method
00347     if ($self->{numerator} < $self->{denominator} ) { $out = $self->print; }
00348 
00349     # otherwise print out the mixed number strong.  This does not alter the
00350     # actual value of the fraction in any way.
00351     else {
00352         my $tempNum = $self->{numerator};
00353         my $tempDenom = $self->{denominator};
00354         my $coeff = int($tempNum/$tempDenom);
00355         $tempNum = $tempNum % $tempDenom;
00356 
00357         $out = " -$coeff \\frac{abs($tempNum)}{abs($tempDenom)} " if ($self->scalar < 0);
00358         $out = " $coeff \\frac{$tempNum}{$tempDenom} " if ($self->scalar > 0);
00359         $out = $coeff if ($tempNum == 0);
00360     }
00361     
00362     $out;
00363 }
00364 
00365 
00366 # prints fraction as 4 or 5/3 as needed
00367 sub print_inline {
00368     my $self = shift;
00369     my $out;
00370 
00371     # if it's a whole number, just print the number
00372     if ($self->{denominator} == 1) {
00373         $out = $self->{numerator};
00374     }
00375     # print as 5/3
00376     else {
00377         $out = "$self->{numerator}/$self->{denominator}";
00378     }
00379     
00380     $out;
00381 }

00383 # these methods are simply so that in a problem, the user may access the variables without 
00384 # worrying about braces, that is, use $frac->denominator instead of $frac->{denominator}
00385 sub numerator {
00386     my $self = shift;
00387     return $self->{numerator};
00388 }
00389 
00390 sub denominator {
00391     my $self = shift;
00392     return $self->{denominator};
00393 }

00395 ########################################################################
00396 # Internal Methods
00397 
00398 # Least Common Multiple
00399 # Used in arithmatic methods to convert two fractions to common denominator
00400 # takes in two scalar values and returns their lcm
00401 sub lcm {
00402     my $self = shift;
00403         my $a = shift;
00404         my $b = shift;  
00405  
00406         #reorder such that $a is the smaller number
00407         if ($a > $b) {
00408                 my $temp = $a;
00409                 $a = $b;
00410                 $b = $temp;
00411         }
00412 
00413         my $lcm = 0;
00414         my $curr = $b;
00415                         
00416         while($lcm == 0) {
00417                 $lcm = $curr if ($curr % $a == 0);
00418                 $curr += $b;
00419         }
00420  
00421         $lcm;
00422 }
00423 
00424 
00425 
00426 # Helper function for reduce
00427 # takes in two scalar values and uses the Euclidean Algorithm to return the 
00428 # greatest common denominator 
00429 sub gcd {   
00430 
00431     my $self = shift;
00432         my $a = abs(shift); #absolute values because this will yeild the same gcd,
00433         my $b = abs(shift); #but allows use of the mod operation
00434 
00435     if ($a < $b) {
00436         my $temp = $a;
00437         $a = $b;
00438         $b = $temp;
00439     }
00440 
00441     return $a if $b == 0;
00442 
00443     my $q = int($a/$b);
00444     my $r = $a % $b;
00445 
00446     return $b if $r == 0;
00447 
00448     my $tempR = $r;
00449     
00450     while ($r != 0) {
00451 
00452         #keep track of what $r was in the last loop, as this is the value 
00453         #we will want when $r is set to 0
00454         $tempR = $r;
00455 
00456         $a = $b;
00457         $b = $r;
00458         $q = $a/$b;
00459         $r = $a % $b;
00460 
00461     }
00462 
00463     $tempR;
00464 }
